description.text: Lutefisk, a traditional Norwegian fish product, was invented by the Vikings as an easier way of instilling fear in their enemies than raiding and pillaging. It is traditionally inflicted upon young Norwegians by their grandparents, and is described by one famous author as 'the world's largest chunk of phlegm.'
It's whatever you want it to be. Just close your eyes and imagine.
It looks like it's been cut right from the steak-beast.
This steak is dripping with thick, rich suffering.
A little age brings out the flavor, right?
Tastes like juicy, delicious, burnt murder.
Another triumph of amateur butchery!
It is gross but at least it stacks nicely.
This is an ur-mass of undifferentiated flesh to which we all one day return.
This pastry is alarmingly unhealthy. Can't you find anything better?
The best thing since itself.
It keeps those creepy doctors away.
Amongst the more deceptive of fruits, the pear is not to be trusted.
Watch out for salmonella!
This is what happens when someone leaves the milk out.
This cheese is from ages long past.
This cheese is from ages long past. Also blue.
A well-rounded cheese.
Allegedly 'one of the best cheeses in existence'.
Yes, it's legit.
Not a cheese to be trifled with.
An adorable little cheese.
It's like a forest of cheese was felled just for you.
It's a blob of cheese.
A homogenized mass of expired dairy product. One hopes you didn't ruin a good cheese for this.
Born of the the bowels of the earth, this omelette quivers chthonically at you.
Born of the gooey union of pre-born broodspawn from the stygian depths and befouled milk, this omelette slouches churlishly, just daring you to taste it.
This is the greasy offspring of an unnatural union of cheese and bread conducted in a high-temperature environment.
Ia ia! This root shall suffer! D'hol nor KLOU FNA'GRU AR KA-LACH OX XIM YALA (et cetera.)
This sandwich is of great stature; It has unmanned better heroes than you. Dare you feed upon its glory?
When a dwarf must drink in the depths of a sewer, Sewer Brew is there to ease his soul.
Light and crisp, this brew puts no 'flavor' or 'body' between a man and his alcohol.
Piratical swill. Ingredients: kerosene, propylene glycol, artificial sweeteners, sulphuric acid, rum, acetone, red dye no. 2, scumm, axle grease, battery acid.
It's cider, it's hard.
It's wine, it's fruity.
From all accounts, 734 was a very good year.
A woodsy nose with a fruitful finish. Tip-top.
God only knows how they stomach this stuff.

item.name: Colonel Miz Stizzix's Old-Time Country-style Bourbon

description.text: It'll put hair on your chest.
Comte Du Fromage Brandy, for the aristocratic drunk.
Finally something good to make from apples.
Fine plum brandy from a kingdom that keeps changing names.
It's like having your brain smashed out with a slice of lemon wrapped around a large gold brick.
Do you know the Green Muse?
It's a big ol' mug of Diggle Nog. If you didn't feel it before, this will fill you up with holiday cheer for sure.

power.name: Boot
power.description: boots your enemies away from you.

power.name: Electrical Strike
power.description: shocks your enemies with bolts of electrical energy.

power.name: Arctic Cold
power.description: freezes the flesh of your enemies.

power.name: Ignition Bolt
power.description: sets your enemies on fire.

power.name: Pyrokinesis
power.description: sets your enemies aflame.

power.name: Fleshbore
power.description: bores into the flesh of your enemies.

power.name: Thaumite Infection
power.description: infects your enemies with ravenous thaumites.

power.name: Midas
power.description: transforms the flesh of your enemies into gold.

power.name: Mini Curse
power.description: curses your enemies with weakness.

power.name: Sleep
power.description: puts your enemies to sleep.

power.name: Nightmare
power.description: sends your enemies into a terrible nightmare.

power.name: Force Blast
power.description: blasts away everything in front of you.

power.name: Blinding Flash
power.description: blinds everyone around you with burning light.

power.name: Rockburst
power.description: pounds your enemies with rocks.

power.name: Dragon's Breath
power.description: shoots of burst of flame toward your enemies.

power.name: Root
power.description: roots your enemies to the ground.

power.name: Blast Effect
power.description: gives you mighty powers of blasting.

power.name: Fire
power.description: starts a fire under your enemies.

power.name: Acid Burn
power.description: burns your enemies with acid.

power.name: Vampirism Attack
power.description: allows you to sap the life of your enemies.

description.text: This crude iron sword was wrought from raw iron and was obviously uncooperative in the operation.
This sword is made of roughly-finished iron, mediocre at best. C+.
A sturdy example of iron swordwork.
A fine example of cutting-edge iron bladework.
This crude steel sword looks like it was pulled rather begrudgingly from a lump of raw steel.
This sword is made of roughly-finished steel, just passable in poor light. From a distance. On choppy seas.
A sturdy steel sword, nothing more.
A bleeding-edge specimen of steelsmithing.
This wooden sword is alarmingly undeadly. Can't you find anything better?
This sword is very, very rusty. Your enemies just might die of tetanus.
This is just a shard of glass awkwardly wrapped up in some string. Don't drop it!
Forged in the maw of a volcano, this 'sword' is edged with obsidian prismatic blades.
This blade is fit for most rotten, villainous buccaneer that ever did plunder booty.
This sword is perfect for conflict resolution methods which are based largely around pit-fighting.
It may be called The General Of All Weapons, but its actual rank is something like Lieutenant Colonel.
For those of you with very manly hands - extra grip!
Perfect for chopping up Romans.
Just don't call it a fatsword.
This totally cool blade will serve you well - in style.
The foundations of chivalry are a good tailor and a long sword.
All the best stuff is made in Japan.
The best axe that was ever a sword.
Lumberjacks tremble when they whisper 'The Tale Of Timberbane'.
Really, it's for their own good.
No one understands you, but still you must fight the darkness ... the darkness within.
This sword always strikes in every way it possibly would. Battery operated.
The three-pronged sword is designed so that if one blade falls off, you still have two left. That's redundancy. That's safety. Don't drink and slay.
The least kosher sword in the dungeon, the Omnipotent Pork Sword sweats with the sweet juices of tasty pig. Ladies love the omnipotent pork sword.

item.name: The Sword of Blork, Son of Dinglenit

description.text: The actual genealogy of this sword is too complicated to think about.
This crudely crafted caricature of an iron axe was ruggedly wrought from raw iron.
This roughly-finished axe is made of iron, roughly.
A sturdy example of iron axework.
A fine example of cutting-edge iron axecraft.
This crude steel axe looks like it was pounded quite unceremoniously from a hunk of raw steel.
This axe is made of roughly-finished steel. It should get the job done, but it won't earn you any friends in the Axe Fanciers Society.
A sturdy steel axe good for cutting down sturdy steeled enemies.
A bleeding-edge specimen of steelsmithing. Truly a cut above.
By paleolithic standards this axe is a high tech terror-weapon. By yours, however, it belongs in a museum.
Best used only for cutting off very small limbs.
A practical axe, suitable for every day hacking and hewing.
Though caked with the putrid blood of demons from many dimensions, this axe otherwise possesses no particular interdimensional powers.
Primarily employed in the cutting of ornamental hedges.
The mighty Samurai Axe! It may not have been used by actual samurai.
Sometimes axes are like razors: The more blades, the better. (The three-bladed axe is stuck in development, following a tragic field test.)
Heft well this weapon of teutonic might! It smells oddly of cabbage.
It's like if an axe neglected to shave for a month.
This axe is appallingly broad to even the most broad-minded Europeans.
Wielded by awesome bards that journey the lands, this axetar will totally shred your enemies with sharp-feeling rocks.
Wielded by the mighty Bard Danieb, this axekeytar will totally shred your enemies with dangerous-looking rocks.

Your enemies are in for some 24 carat dismemberment! And yes, gold is an extremely soft metal entirely unsuited for axecraft. We're just going to go ahead say that it's magic that keeps the thing sharp. Seriously, you should be chopping baddies up, not worrying about plausible metallurgical practices.
When you've got a bone to pick with a monster, pick this weapon because then you've got an axe.
Clockwork mechanisms power the running teeth of this mechanical terror.
The blade of this axe cuts both time and space. It should suffice to say that if you tried to split firewood with it, terrible, lumber-related things would happen to other worlds.
This crudely crafted caricature of an iron mace was ruggedly wrought from raw iron.
This roughly-finished mace is made of iron, roughly.
A sturdy example of iron macework.
A fine example of cutting-edge iron macecraft.
This crude steel mace looks like it was pounded quite unceremoniously from a hunk of raw steel.
This mace is made of roughly-finished steel. It should crush most opposition.
A sturdy steel mace good for smashing down sturdy steeled enemies.
A bleeding-edge specimen of steelsmithing. Pounds away the competition.
This club is essentially a malformed stick. Gnarly.
This is irrefutable evidence of Dredmor's nefarious plans.
Giant black rectangles just make you SO. ANGRY.
It's Nailboard(tm), the finest in Boards-in-Nails technology. Also functions as a holepunch.
This is what you get when a branch off the Ugly Tree has a run-in with a sack of nails.
This wrench is good for both tightening nuts and bashing skulls.
Gives your opponents the last lesson in practical geology they'll ever need.
It's a mace, eminently suitable for beating your enemies' heads in.
It's a flail, suitable as a conversation-starter and awkwardly hitting people with great force.
Stop. It's that time again.
The Employee Wage Transfrobulator was created by Lord Dredmor to deal with union disagreements.
Small and unassuming, this flail has a way of lodging itself in unexpected craniums.
It's not a pretty sight, but it gets the job done.
This'll knock your enemy into the next dungeon over.
Mind boggling to use, this flail can prove highly effective in the hands of a skilled operator.
For when you need to distribute a first-class pummeling.
It's the Mace of Lobster. It dishes out violence in the traditional crustacean manner.
This mace is imbued with burning, gut-wrenching power drawn from the fiery bowels of the earth.
This flail is imbued with burning, mind-bending power drawn from the shining stars of the sky.
Sometimes people cannot distinguish between a leader who solves problems efficiently and a leader who is evil. These people are efficaciously silenced through the application of this mace.
The Nailboard(TM) Mark II is revolutionizing combat woodwork. This prototype is not certified for field use.
When the Dwarves ran out of iron, they made bone bolts. When they ran out of bone, they made wood bolts. When they ran out of wood, they made these.
It's an exceptionally standard bolt constructed below Bolt Council standards. An impressive feat!
Crafted of copper, this bolt has some nasty barbs. Too bad it's copper.
A cruel and crafty mind was behind the manufacture of these copper bolts. Too bad they're made of copper, which is pretty useless for this sort of thing.
It's an exceptionally standard bolt constructed with a loose interpretation of Bolt Council standards.
Crafted of bronze, this bolt has some nasty barbs.
A cruel and crafty mind was behind the manufacture of these bronze bolts.
It's an exceptionally standard bolt constructed to meet Bolt Council specifications.
Crafted of iron, this bolt has some nasty barbs.
A cruel and crafty mind was behind the manufacture of these iron bolts.
It's an exceptionally standard bolt constructed to meet Bolt Council specifications.
Crafted of steel, this bolt has some nasty barbs.
A cruel and crafty mind was behind the manufacture of these steel bolts.
Invented by the Wizard Tesla, these bolts shocked the crossbowing world upon their introduction.
Originally invented to assist in long-range carpentry, the tragic prototype test results spurred unintended breakthroughs in weapon technologies.
In the darkest days of the Third Elven War this barbarous device was unveiled by the Undermountain Clans to terrible effect.
'Who would make such things?' the conscript pleaded, his life draining from horrible wounds. 'The Dwarves' replied the watch-captain, 'Those bastards.'
The deadly potential of copper brazenly flows from the end of this bolt.
The deadly potential of bronze is draped resplendently on the end of this bolt.
The deadly potential of iron blossoms curiously on the end of this bolt.
The deadly potential of steel blooms artfully at the end of this bolt.
Best used for practice. And for killing vampires. But don't be silly, vampires aren't real.
Due to popular demand Bolt Classic has been brought back. It's the bolt you love, the bolt you take home, the bolt you grew up with. Bolt Classic. (This message funded by the Bolt Council.)
The product of a misguided marketing campaign, 'New Bolt' failed spectacularly to capture the urban demographic and so was dumped on hinterland markets.
These bolts have a wider cutting surface which, through subtle magic, do not get caught in the crossbow's frame.
The fire bolt is good for igniting thatched-roof cottages.
From the dark and icy north come these bolts carved by Dwarven bone-crafters from the still-twitching remains of fearsome undead skeletal elk. They still thirst for the blood of the living.
An ampoule of poison has been placed on the end of this bolt.

These bolts are perfect for the adventurer of supple morals. It has one (1) bottle of vile poison attached to the business end which, upon impact, shatters and sends poisonous shards of eco-friendly low-phosphorous glass flying willy-nilly and hither-thither.
Acid: Make a splash!
Acid: Make a splash!
Sleek. Fresh. The Bolt of the Future. Bolt Moderne.
These bolts have little skulls on the end. Creepy!
Where lesser bolts have failed, a Bolt of Squid will deliver tentacled, inky, cephalopodic doom. Ia!
This bolt contains terrible energies. You are become death, destroyer of dungeons!
Getting hit with one of these hurts more than you might imagine.
This doesn't return to you after you throw it. Dwarves never could master boomerang-crafting.
Try explaining these to the customs officer.
You're going to put someone's eye out with this.
These are probably a lot less cool than you think they are, being little more than glorified gardening tools, but popular demand is what it is.
Not just for the pub anymore!
You're a ninja!
It's not unlike a long-range kebab.
These are the happy by-product of a failed long-range lumberjack initiative.
An odd sort of throwing axe.
Though very soft, this puffball also creates a cloud of highly-confusing toxic spores upon impact.
Put it on your salad for a delicious dish, or dump it on your enemies for fiery vengeance.
Wear your goggles when handling this one.
Poison gas - don't breathe this.
A potent nearly-potable fiery bomb. Don't spill.
This is the sort of thing you'd construct in the free time which comes from living alone in a shack out in the middle of the woods.
Have a blast with the Concussion Bomb! It stuns and pushes enemies.
Start a flame which can burn through steel and can't be snuffed.
Let's go out with a bang.
Point the sharp end at the enemy.
You're going to blow someone's eye up with this.
'O Lord, bless this, thy hand grenade.'
Though tough, this unsophisticated iron crossbow only just barely manages to hit targets.
This hardy iron crossbow lands a solid bolt.
This clever iron lever crossbow lands a solid bolt indeed.
This complicated iron rachet crossbow drives a bolt home with fearsome power.
Though tough, this unsophisticated steel crossbow only just barely manages to hit targets.
This hardy steel crossbow lands a solid bolt.
This clever steel lever crossbow lands a solid bolt indeed.
This complicated steel rachet crossbow drives a bolt home with fearsome power.
It's like a kid's toy. Adorable, sure, but you may as well just throw the bolts at bad guys.
Those who cross you while you wield this piece of hardware will wish you didn't have a crossbow.
The patented Mr. Cranky(tm) crossbow reloading crank system means that even the most languorous aristocrat can reload this heavy steel crossbow with ease.
This spring steel double bowed crossbow comes in handy when you need to double your armor-piercing punch. Comes with handy crossbow crank for Liquid Smooth(tm) reloading.
This crossbow is of the sort commonly used by agents of the Bolt Council to assassinate kings who outlaw crossbows. Suppressor attachment not pictured.
Hunt monsters with this fetishized commodity -- because you're worth it.
Pew pew!
And they said that the march of technology would never replace the crossbow! (Keep moving parts well oiled. Do not operate in humid to semi-humid conditions. Excessive jostling may void warranty.)
This stick from a moderately tough tree is useful for hitting people.
Why use one staff when you can haphazardly use two at the same time? (Because it's really awkward.)
This staff belongs in a seedy magical pawn shop.
This staff is purpose-made for hitting people.
It looks like someone bent this staff trying to pry open the void which binds the world-spheres together.
For the wizard of classical taste. Must be polished daily.
Wow, how do they get that orb to just hover there? It's like magic!
Using this staff will give you ideas you had no idea you had.
This staff is both a device for channeling magical energy and a dispenser of nature's tasty treats: fruit.
It's like a broom ran into a chandelier.
Brood with the gloomiest necromancer with this spooky stick.
Triangulon The Magniloquent iterated through many versions of this staff before constructing one that worked as intended. This one is powerful, if of dubious character.
They say that the power of The Wizard Moravic doubles every year. This staff was one of his earlier designs.
This staff was used by Lekon in his travels to project distracting humorous images at his enemies.
Wait, you mean everything ISN'T supposed to be all blurry?
A crudely-crafted iron helm.
A roughly-crafted iron helm for a roughly-crafted Viking warrior.
This is the helm of a Viking warrior. Where's the mead?
This helm is fit for a warrior from the great sagas!
This excellent aluminum helm, when worn, makes you both sound and look like robot.
It may make a ridiculous hat, but at least you won't get hit by a car.
You don't want to think about what this bucket has been used for, nor do you wish to consider the fact that desperate times might force you to wear it on your head.

It's not clear whether this rusty helm is from the future, the past, or some kind of elder world beyond human ken. And it's a pity about the boring brown palette, a little color would make this helm much livelier. Or so they say.
Be a horned warrior!

This knight's helm looks a lot like a bucket if a bucket had a hole cut in it for you to see through and a visor you could raise to eat through. These features would not be useful on most buckets, however.
It's hard to see out of this huge metal thing but on the upside it makes you sound a little like a robot when you talk.
This helmet was crafted by dwarven smiths in ages long past from the weapons cast down by the dying goblins foolish enough to attack their undermountain fortress.
This is one of many hats in the dungeon that you can poke your eye out on.
A cap fit for even the foulest peasant.
These can protect your eyes from flying mechanisms and scalding steam; Yea, you could build a veritable empire of clockwork.
It keeps your ears warm, eh.
No time for love, Dr. Jones?
It's not really a good hat for hunting vampires in, but what do you expect from somebody who thinks that spelling DRACULA backwards is a good way to hide their identity?
It's... a magical sombrero. Vaya con dios!
This yellow crown is made of some kind of resinous excretion. It feels almost warm to the touch.

It is said that Sir Albrecht once successfully ignored the devil and, on a separate but related occasion, ran away from death. It is unclear what his helm had to do with any of this except for its notable reduction of peripheral vision.
Wearing this hat causes you to feel more centered in the universe.
You were assured that the sigil on this hat meant 'strength' but it's actually the Urrish sign for 'naive foreigner'.
This headband makes it seem like a good idea to destroy common architectural materials with your bare hands.
Though gauche from a fashion perspective, these do keep the ichor off your feet.
These bronze greaves will protect your shins.
These dazzling bronze greaves will protect your shins in style.
These copper boots are awkward, but will help to conduct voltaic energies around you.
These iron boots may be heavy but they are certainly excellent for stomping.
These fancy aluminum boots are light and considered highly fashionable in certain circles.
Perfect for the beach or pool.
This product has never been worn by an actual gladiator, but it makes you feel like one, and *that* is what matters.
Carved from the dutchest of woods, these shoes are surprisingly comfortable.
Try to die with these on.
Impeccably fancy, these boots make you feel like a dancing queen!
These boots were made for crushing and that's just what they'll do.
Rob carriages and sweep strumpets out of their bodices with these swashbuckling boots of leather the color of deepest eggplant.
Never again worry about dropping that plate armor on your toe with these boots.
Made from 100% organic hemp, you feel like so close to the world in these, you know?
Only the most immorally opulent footwear for you.
These boots are simply out of this world.
This is the sort of shield used by Heroes of Yore. It's in pretty rough shape.
This is the sort of shield used by Heroes of Yore. Fortunately, you've never met anyone from Yore.
This is the sort of shield used by Heroes of Yore in myths involving great peril and renown!
This is the shield of your Viking Ancestors! The poorer ones, that is.
This is the shield of your Viking Ancestors! It feels like a good time to pillage some villages.
This is the shield of your Viking Ancestors! You feel like you could plunder monasteries and devour lutefisk!
It looks like this orb was knocked off a high shelf.
This orb glitters like sunlight through the leaves of the forest canopy.
This orb swirls with dark clouds. It mostly just wants to brood in the corner.
This sphere is studded with wires and crackles with electricity. The smell of ozone lingers about.
You can see billions and billions of stars in the depths of this orb.
Hot to the touch, flames roil inside this orb.
This orb is weightless but massy, and no light escapes its circumference. Hopefully nothing ever escapes.
It'll block a stiff breeze, but not a heck of a lot more.
The trusty rusty metal buckler. It can block many things, but not the ravages of time.
Try to do a better job with this shield than the last guy, will you?
This shield is soft, fuzzy, and pleasant, though a bit moist.
Wood: If it's good enough for the trees, it's good enough for you!
This beaten-up wooden shield has a large, expensive-looking gem stuck in the middle. It seems there's no way to pry it out, so you'll just have to take the package as-is.
Light, shiny, and spiky, it's the buckler that helps you fight back!
This would look great on a tapestry, though you suspect that it wouldn't fly very well.
This swashbucklin' shield is distressingly small and therefore encourages attack. It might also be useful for reflecting the sun into people's eyes if you weren't underground.
This shield just screams 'have a wonderful day' at you.
A shield made of hide worth hiding... behind.
It's just a regular shield. I don't know why they call it that.
You could do some serious baking on this thing, maybe shutter a lavaspout; whatever.
You'd have half the life expectancy if you didn't use this lovely shield.
This shield functionally blocks barbarian assaults but not internal social collapse. Snap!
You feel like holding this above your head and scuttling into a safe, dark corner.
Whoever made this shield clearly has no appreciation for negative space in a composition because it is completely covered by sigils of magical protection.
This shield is itself a giant rune of protection.
Though most of the nourishing sap has been drained, the little that remains imbues this wooden shield with surprising strength.
Be shielded by your doubt!
No, really.
This is madness! No; This ... Is ... CAKETOWN!!!
Sturdy and dutiful, this forged iron cuirass can save your life if you're not too careful.
Crafted of thick steel, this cuirass will serve you well..
A rough bronze cuirass. The real question is 'why?'.
You know what they say - 'When in Greece...'
Wearing this, you feel as though you could conquer a large portion of the known world!
This fine aluminum cuirass is so light it makes you feel like you could fly away.
Pleather armour was invented by the Dwarven Plasticsmiths to provide a cheap, ethical alternative to leather armour.
The oft-maligned Plastic Platemail is both light and economical but has fared poorly in nearly all combat tests.
'Do you feel magic? Well do ya, punk?'
This breastplate has seen better days. Hopefully it serves you better than it did its previous owner.
A leather coat covered in metal knobs, it's the studliest coat you've seen yet.
This fine steel breastplate has been lovingly polished to a mirror-smooth sheen.
It's a bit like wearing a metal crocodile.
A leather tunic with steel plates riveted inside; Bulky but practical around the house.
A suit of mail made by interlocking fine rings of metal. This provides great ventilation for the physically active warrior.
The medieval equivalent of the private jet, this cleverly articulated armour has been meticulously crafted from steel plates.
It is said that a suit of magic armor was made from a piece of star-metal that fell from the sky. This is not that armor, but it could pass for it.
A crisp white shirt of the sort worn by gentleman rogues. Don't spill on it!
Wearing this tunic will make you the dandiest fop in all the land.
Wearing this tunic will make you the most ostentatious popinjay in the entire dungeon.
This leather cuirass really lets your outfit *breathe*.
It's a stylin' hide.
A fine piece of equipment used by bandits of high esteem everywhere.
A simple cloth robe, of the sort worn by monks, priests, and Noel Coward.
Once a simple robe, the cloth has been transformed into a material as pliant as fine cambric but as strong as hardened steel.
This robe is so out of fashion that only a great magician could wear it.
A mage on the rise in the world needs an outfit that makes a statement. With deadly-pointy shoulder pads, impractically long sleeves, and peripheral vision-blocking collar, *this* is that outfit.
With the life of a mage such as it is, the need for an armored yet stylish robe is painfully clear.
This cloak is filled with billions and billions of stars.
With the life of an arch-mage such as it is, the need for an armored yet stylish robe is painfully clear. Comes with additional hardened iron back-stab deflection plate inserts.
Take your best shot.
Makes you look tough. Evidently we DO need another hero.
This robe was worn by Lekon the Seer in his adventures through a multitude of strange lands. It smells like it, too.
Such armor may save even you from inevitable doom.
The mystical powers of the Wizard's Sleeve are many. If only you had a slot for sleeves on your character sheet.
Stained with the chalk of many battles, this sturdy coat enhances your thaumaturgic acumen beyond what linear arithmetic would suggest.
It's a copper torc!
For the urbane adventurer.
This necklace will leave you feeling as ornate as you are ostentatious.
This amulet acts as a conduit to past wisdom about the secrets of life, death, and black eyeliner.
A glittering sapphire hangs from a silver necklace.
Blingity Bling.
A gleaming emerald hangs from a platinum necklace.
This amulet is wrought from the finest Dwarven plastics and copper wiring; it sparkles with mysterious voltaic energies.
A shoddy plastic ring in the Dwarven style. Why do they make so many of these?
A plainly crafted copper ring. Conductive.
A plainly crafted iron ring. Spartan, eh?
A stylishly crafted silver ring. Sophisticated.
An elegantly crafted gold ring. Blingity bling!
This elegantly crafted gold ring is set with an intimidatingly large emerald.
This elegantly crafted gold ring is overgrown to the point of poor taste by richly inset emeralds.
A cosmopolitan electrum ring. Subtle yet evocative.
A robust bronze ring. Classical yet timeless.
A dandy brass ring. Academic yet grounded.
This ring is surprisingly light on the digit.
This ring is made of electrum strands cleverly enmeshed with a copper base. They form arcane voltaic geometries.
This ring is wreathed with malevolent iron spikes.
This silvery-platinum band pulses with focused thaumaturgic energy.
This byzantine collection of gears, springs, and braces will augment the power of any limb you strap into it. Keep this well oiled and don't splash too much ichor around the moving parts.
This byzantine collection of gears, springs, and braces will augment the power of any limb you strap into it. Keep this well oiled and don't splash too much ichor around the moving parts.
This ring has already been burned.
This ring is made of something leathery. Probably best not to think about it too much. Or at all.
Pretty much the worst ring possible.
This uncomfortable (and rusty) square iron ring is made for beings more angular than yourself. Possibly robots.
A highly conductive coppery arc.
This uncomfortable (yet shiny) square ring is made for beings more angular than yourself. Possibly robots.
A sturdy steel ring.
This metal ring is pleasingly twisted.
The copper ring inspires you to conduct yourself as befits a gentleman.
Bewitchingly stylish.
This mushroom smells of rich fungal liquor.
This is one of those herbal remedies that people take to try to make themselves bigger.
This cool, smooth fungus is just seeping with rich magicks.
The Fell Truffle is the only mushroom in the world that can leap out of the ground and throttle a truffle-hunting pig.
Apart from its better-known toughening effects, this fungus may cause an appreciation for flannel.
It's highly puffy and full of confusing spores.
Known to grow upon and consume boots, often avoided by seasoned adventurers. Excellent with a lemon sauce. Grants ability to drain lifeforce.
Every year, tiny fairies collect these rare, healing fungi in preparation for the event known only as the great Wodger Festival.
The fruiting body of the Inky Hoglantern only blooms in the middle of the deepest night of the year. Good thing you're finding these in a dungeon.
Grows in muck and often mistaken for its medium, the Mud Wen is strangely resistant to transmutative energies.
A regal mushroom better feared than loved.
Easily mistaken for true Lobstermane, the Lobstermane fungus is the foundation of a grey-market economy in shoddy culinary substitutes.
Nature finds a way.
So is it violet or purple?
It shines the delicate blue of a sky you'll never see again.
Way better than Sard and would make an excellent gift to an Assyrian astronomer. If you knew any.
It's like a party in the palm of your hand.
A most lush and verdant gem; it sparkles cautiously at you.
It shines coldly in the earth.
Only the cream of the sea for ye.
A tempestuous, lusty gem; it glares redly.
Cold, blue, and glittering like the deepest sea.
It is not to be mistaken for aqua or cyan.
A girl's best friend. Shiny!

item.name: My Little Anvil Junior Smithing Kit

description.text: What all the Young Dwarves want this summer. Comes with anvil, forge, bucket of water, and tiny hammer and clamps. Smithing IS Magic!
Just the thing for the potions master who needs to brew fame, bottle glory or stopper death while on the run from masked lunatics in the Old Country.
For the homebrewer in a hurry.
It's a shoddily manufactured disposable ingot press, probably made for export to Goblin markets.
The Elven Ingot Grinder: designed as a weapon in a war against the Dwarves which never came. Who knows what good they thought it would be? Made of soy and xanthan gum; for single use only.
An inexhaustible supply of junk used for most tinkering applications.
The standard tool for wizards who want to repair or modify magical devices that exist in The Other Planes. But ... what is the correct value of n?
Lutefisk for the Lutefisk God!
A source of copper, traditionally used in casting the Dwarven Microzorkmid. Just what you need - now you can make your own Microzorkmids.
Mined from deposits found alongside roads and in city parks, this ore is the lifeblood of the Dwarven plasticsmithing guilds.
A source of tin, but who's watching anyway?
A delightful source of zinc.
A grudging source of aluminum.
A source of iron, Hematite is much prized by the discerning metallurgist. You can also make yogurt out of it.
A source of silver, there's hidden treasure inside.
An obvious source of gold, there's shiny treasure inside this rock.
A source of platinum, there's shiny treasure inside this rock.
Some call it 'The Thinking Man's Coal'.
It's white, dry, and doesn't taste very interesting. It's chalk.
Light, cheerful, and utterly nonbiodegradable.
This is a very large bar of copper, just waiting to be converted into delightful gourmet cookware.
Yeah, it's brass again.
Tin! It's pretty much only good for making bronze because Lord Dredmor hid the secret of pewter-making as part of his terrible plans for the world.
Zinc - one of the three Forbidden Metals.
Bronze! It is the most artistic metal, vanadium aside. Critics be damned.
It's an iron ingot. Ironic, isn't it? Not really.
The steel ingot is a testament to the fact that you'd really rather be playing some other video game with a more finely honed crafting system. Oh well...
Commonly used for aeronautical plate armour.
It's a brick of solid gold. (Expatriated Latvian with a giant, gold-melting, crotch-ripping laser beam not included.)
Powdered aluminum is a strictly controlled substance in Dwarven society.
This probably used to be something useful.
Everyone's favourite condiment: Salt.
Anyone with a handful of this is clearly up to no good. Or they're making preserves. In short: no good.
A pile of foul-smelling sulphur. Yes, it is a most diabolical substance!
This is a handful of fun just waiting to happen.
This flask, extra shatter-prone, is filled to the brim with hopes and dreams.
Whatever will you make with this?
Useful for conducting the flow of voltaic energies. Keep an eye on this wire though, Kobolds are known to steal it.
This collection of meticulously-crafted brass widgets and doodads can be used to construct precise mechanisms.
A shocking device first created by the Wizard Tesla, it can be used to store and discharge voltaic energies.
Feeling a little wound up? This is a spring-powered source of kinetic energy for use in mechanisms of all kinds.
A mechanical triggering mechanism for constructing traps. Whatever will you make with this?
Considered a traditional Dwarven greeting, stepping on this pressure plate releases a boulder from overhead.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a large spinning arrow at you. Ow!
This is a sub-par Dwarven IED design. All craftsdwarfship is pretty lousy, actually.
This trap swings a fairly crude axe-blade at the poor sod standing in the way.
Sprays poison gas everywhere.
It's like a surprise barbeque!
A swift end is likely to follow whoever steps on this trap.
Robo-bolt Zap!
Sprays corrosive acid all over the place.
The Wizard Tesla designed these electrical generators to power a grand new age of thaumological progress, but instead smaller minds turned them into weapons. Also, this version is not inexhaustible.
This trap swings a rough axe-blade at the poor sod standing in the way.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a large spinning arrow at you. Ow!
When triggered, this mine taps into the Elemental Plane of Saunas to spray scalding steam everywhere.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a large spinning bolt of aethereal energy at you. Ow!
This is a standard defense of mage's manses; It discharges burning aethereal energy then paralyzes the intruder.
A swarm of Thaumites lives trapped in this magic circle - when triggered, they are released to consume whatever hapless creature wanders by.
This trap swings an axe-blade at the poor sod standing in the way.
This awful fungus sprays corrosive acid all over the place.
A terrifying fungal trap that damages your equipment. Fortunately, it takes over five hundred years for the trap to recharge its supply of fluid, so it will only affect you once.
This trap consists of a quivering pustule of toxic slime which will explode at the slightest touch.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a large shard of ice at you. Brr!
This trap stores up the tremendous pressure of glacial ice and lets it loose all at once upon the unwary.
This trap contains highly-pressurized blinding, choking mist. Point away from face when operating. If contents are ingested, contact a physician.
These carefully tuned mechanisms spray rocks at hapless passerbys upon triggering.
The Blingmine is a diabolical creation of the Dwarves, those bastards.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a fiery mass at you. Ow!
It goes boom; those bastard Dwarves.
Sprays choking, burning, biting brimstone fumes in a large, unpleasant cloud.
The Elder Rune of Incandescence causes the unwary to burst into a column of flame.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to spit a bolt of terrifying tentacular infestation.
A viscous crimson fluid fills this small flask.
This lush green poison seems to have filaments suspended in its fluid.
This is a small potion of deepest blue; it whorls slowly, magically, at you.
This flask glows at you like a clear sky.
A weighty gray fluid sulks coldly at the bottom of this flask.
The fluid in this flask shines brightly and is difficult to look at directly. You're in for a flash.
Tiny ivory vortices play about in this flask's fluid. This potion will replenish your life and mana.
Inky black liquid swirls of its own accord in this flask.
This potion is spoken of only in hushed tones by the Dwarven Glittersmiths and never mentioned by name. The flask is filled with a shimmering gold fluid.
This flask is filled to the brim with cheerful pinkness.
This small yellow potion fizzes quietly to itself with promises of a clean slate.
This dark potion churns gloomily with necromantic bubbles.
This fiery potion flickers and glows. It is hot to the touch.
This potion crackles coolly from time to time. Moisture condenses on the flask.
Fulminaric energies swirl around and around in this potion. The flask occasionally arcs.
After you drink this potion, wherever you go, there you are.
This fluid is foul and largely unappealing.
It's the salty acid! Not good on your potatoes.
This is some -strong- sort of water.
Also known as 'The Alchemist's Friend'. It'll do considerably more than rot your teeth if you drink it.
The primary building block of alchemy: 100% pure alcohol.
Delicious, delicious gold.
Crafted by the feared Wizard Tesla, this wand tingles with inconceivable power.
Need a hand with magic? Well, here you go.
This wand is bony, unpleasant, and starts to quiver whenever you point it at a corpse. Hmm.
This wand is funny-smelling and it might have just moved a little.
The power of bling is not a power to be taken lightly.
This wand appears to be a piece of arcane machinery graven with magic runes.
The motions of these tiny spheres reflects the sky somewhere far above. What's your sign?
This wand is pretty fabulous, all told. It's also a decent exfoliator.
It burns with the fires of magical essence imbued deep within.
Not to be confused with the rock wand, this looks like someone snapped off a stalactite and turned it into a wand.
Not to be confused with the stony wand, this wand looks like it was dug up out of a quarry.
Aside from some tangential properties, this wand's primary magical power involves distracting cats.
Wearing these helps avoid unsightly Adventuring Calluses.
These gloves are eerily supple. Just play along.
Thick, sturdy gloves. You could just rub bricks all day. If you're into that.
These are sneaky hand-coats; useful for prying into places you don't belong.
Battle-mittens like these are worn by Kanadian warriors in their sacred war against the hosts of Hyperborea.
Fit for the most fabulous privateer that ever corsaired, these gloves reek of bounty. And low tide.
They're the best hand protection money can buy, but gods help you if you need to tie your shoes.
This glove holds magic in its palm. Yes, just the one.
The hottest gloves on the market. (You'll be throwing with fire, see.)
It's a belt. It helps keep your pants up and provides peace of mind.
Avast! This belt be a fine prize fer plunderin'.
It girds your meats while accenuating your figure.
The impressive-looking plaque on this belt will thoroughly convince enemies of your combat prowess.
The rattling of these heavy iron plates should scare away your enemies before you even see them. At least that seems to be the operating notion at work.

The pouches of this belt are filled with a comprehensive set of traditional Viking hex-wrenches and well-folded parchments illuminated with text-free depictions of the steps required to disarm sundry categories of the most popular dungeon trap designs from the last thousand years.
This style of sash features a charming pattern of stars' arrangement in the sky accurate to the particular moment of viewing. (Is that a stain or a comet?)

Though it causes restriction of movement and bloodflow to the lower extremities, this girdle of finely polished steel plates serves very nicely to protect the soft and mushy parts that monsters keep trying to bite.
It's not clear if these pants have ever been washed.
'It's a real medical condition!'
Proper breeches are the first step on the road to becoming a mighty pirate.
The Germans are a strange people.
Being able to *breathe* really helps when you're swinging a claymore around.
Because it is simply impossible to touch these.
You just wear them for the insulation. Really.
From awe-inspiring codpiece to hand-sculpted ankle-sockets, these gleaming trousers are a paragon of the Armouring Arts.
The Elves created these traps to prevent the Dwarves from casting magic. The Dwarves just lopped the Elves' knees off.
Once upon a time, this wand was turgid with power. Now it's just garbage.
Viscous crimson fluids fill this gleaming vessel.
Beyond the stopper atop this flask is a swirling sea of potent alchemical talent in fluid form.
You hold the tingly power of the Aetherial Spheres in this cylinder; the energies rebel tempestuously at their imposed geometry.
These are as perfect for imparting variable motion output from rotational sources as they are awful for making necklaces. But fear not: Science marches on!
This component is absolutely vital to the proper functioning of an endless list of sundry, vaguely miscellaneous devices.
Crush your enemies and see them driven before you. Show them the true power of Krong's steel.
Holding this, you feel a strange urge to form a mob and attack scientists and other types of witches.
It's like a staff with some kind of sharpened shovel stuck on the end, okay?
It's like a staff with a knife stuck on the end, okay?
See your enemies crushed before you from afar!
This weapon has three times the pointiness of a regular spear!
Though rude to bring this to a non-partisan conflict, the effect is certainly striking.
'Strike now with the power of neutrality!'
Run! It's the moon blade!
So you just put a katana on the end of a pole - how is this considered honourable?
Carved from the tooth of a dragon, one of the ferocious beasts who ruled the world when it was as yet molten and unformed, this lance burns with an unquenchable flame.
Not to be confused with the Lava Lance. That one starts fires; this one explodes.
This vicious-looking spear was rebranded as a weapon after the Alchemists' Guild overruled, by unanimous decision, its creator's attempts to market it as a cosmetic device for skin exfoliation.
Sure, it LOOKS awesome...
Ground from a piece of scrap metal, this weapon isn't even classy enough to stick hors d'oeuvres.
Cuts cake just as poorly as it does people.
No, dirk you!
The Bronze Age was known for its many innovations in the growing fields of metallurgy and murder.
This whirling blade efficiently turns animals into food and people into corpses.
The Hyperboreans believe the world will end in frozen darkness, and do what they can to accelerate the process.
In the dark and dismal lands of Ulm, it is customary to greet a guest by stabbing them. Honoured guests are stabbed twice.
Originally designed with a clap-on, clap-off feature, this was later removed due to lost digits and accidental fires.
As long as it is kept wound, this dagger keeps perfect time, even submerged in water up to a depth of 100 feet. It also kills people.
What they don't tell you is that it also makes a serviceable breadknife.

An ancient despot commissioned this dagger from a dwarven forgemaster as part of a set of flatware, but when he refused to pay, the dagger was cursed. He died later at the dinner table from a spontaneous outbreak of internal wealth.
Sworn enemy of Pumpkinns, he carved his way to the foot of the Great Pumpkinn's lair before succumbing to clouds of poison and rot.
Ockham invented his razor to fight against wizards, obviously.

It was indeed the Wizard Moravic who made this dagger to win some sort of boast made in a Wizard Pub; the blade branches and branches and branches down to the smallest possible thaumaturgon-scale. It can stab a thousand, thousand wounds in one thrust. (Moravic is no longer allowed in said pub.)
